column3: Question Text
A position dependent force, $F=\left(7-2 x+3 x^{2}\right) \mathrm{N}$ acts on a small body of mass $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ and displaces it from $x=0$ to $x=5 \mathrm{~m}$. The work done (in joule) is
column11:
$\int d W=\int F d x$
$W=\int_{0}^{5}\left(7-2 x+3 x^{2}\right) d x$
$W=135$ joule

If the two collide at the highest point of the trajectory of $B$, the angle of projection is given by
A container is accelerating with acceleration $a=g$ along the direction as shown below. Find the angle $\theta$ made by the liquid surface with the vertical wall of the container.

A soap film is formed on a triangular wire frame having two fixed and one movable side. The free side is moved with a constant acceleration ' $a$ '. Take side length to be zero at $t=0$ as shown. If the surface tension is constant and $U$ is the surface potential energy of the soap film then
column11:
$Y=\frac{1}{2} a t^{2}$
$F=2 T Y$
$P=F . V$
$P=2 T \times \frac{1}{2} a t^{2} . a t$
$P \propto t^{3}$

column3: A plank of mass $m$ placed over a solid cylinder of mass $m$ and radius $R$, is pulled by a constant horizontal force $F$ as shown in figure. There is no slipping anywhere. The acceleration of plank is
column11: $F \times 2 R=\left(\frac{3}{2} m R^{2}+m \times 4 R^{2}\right)\left(\frac{a}{2 R}\right) \Rightarrow a=\frac{8 F}{11 m}$

column3: A wire of conical shape of length $L$ and end radii $r_{1}$ and $r_{2}$ is stretched by two forces $F$ applied parallel to the length in opposite directions normal to the end faces as shown. If $Y$ denotes the Young's modulus of elasticity, then extension produced is
column11: $\Delta L=\frac{F L}{Y A}=\frac{F L}{Y \sqrt{A_{1} A_{2}}}=\frac{F L}{Y \sqrt{\pi r_{1}^{2} \pi r_{2}^{2}}}=\frac{F L}{Y \pi r_{1} r_{2}}$

column3: The speed of planet at apogee in terms of eccentricity(e) is (a is semimajor axis of ellipse)

An object of mass $3 \mathrm{~kg}$ is projected from a point on a horizontal plane with speed $20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ at angle $60^{\circ}$ with horizontal. The object explodes at the highest point and breaks into two parts of masses $1 \mathrm{~kg}$ and $2 \mathrm{~kg}$. The fragment of mass $1 \mathrm{~kg}$ moves horizontally at speed $15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ in backward direction just after explosion. The distance of centre of mass from the point of projection when the two parts hit the plane is $\left(g=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)$
column11:
Motion of COM does not altered by explosion.
$x=R=\frac{(20)^{2} \times \sin \left(120^{\circ}\right)}{10}=20 \sqrt{3} \mathrm{~m}$

column3:
An open organ pipe of length $l$ is sounded together with another organ pipe of length $l+x$ in their respective fundamental tones (given $x<<l$ ). The beat frequency heard will be ?
(speed of sound is $v$)
column11:
$l=\frac{\lambda_{1}}{2} \therefore \lambda_{1} \Rightarrow 2 l$
$\therefore f_{1}=\frac{v}{2 I}$
Similarly $f_{2}=\frac{v}{2 l\left(1+\frac{x}{l}\right)}=\frac{v}{2 l}\left(1-\frac{x}{l}\right)$
$\therefore \Delta f=f_{1}-f_{2}=\frac{v}{2 l}\left(1-1+\frac{x}{l}\right)=\frac{v x}{2 l^{2}}$

column3: A faulty thermometer has ice point at $-5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and steam point at $105^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. What would be the temperature shown by this thermometer of human body? (Assume correct temperature of human body is $37^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$)
Time period of oscillation of given arrangement is
column11:
$x=2 x_{1}+2 x\left(2 x_{1}\right)$
$\therefore m \frac{d^{2} x}{d t^{2}}=-\frac{k x}{6}$
$\Rightarrow T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{6 m}{k}}$

column3: One half mole of a monatomic ideal gas absorbs $1200 \mathrm{~J}$ of energy while performing $2196 \mathrm{~J}$ of work. The temperature of the gas changes by
column11:
$\Delta Q=\Delta U+\Delta W$
$1200 \mathrm{~J}=\Delta U+2196 \mathrm{~J}$
$\Delta U=1200-2196=-996$
$n C_{v} \Delta T=\Delta U$
$\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{3}{2} \times 8.314 ~\Delta T=996(-$ ve $)$
$\Delta T \cong-160^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$

column3: A point charge $Q$ is located just outside an imaginary hemispherical surface of radius $R$ as shown in the figure given below. The electric flux passing through curved surface of the hemisphere is
column11: Net electric flux through the surface is zero $\phi$ (Curved surface) $+\phi$ (Flat surface) $=0$ $\phi$ Curved surface $=-\phi$ (Flat surface) $\phi$ (Flat surface) $=\frac{Q}{2 \varepsilon_{0}}(1-\cos \phi)=\frac{Q}{2 \varepsilon_{0}}\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)$

column3: A resistance $R$ of thermal coefficient of resistivity $\alpha$ is connected in parallel with a resistor $3 R$ having thermal coefficient of resistivity $2 \alpha$. Equivalent thermal coefficient of resistivity for the combination is

An electron is moving in a circular orbit of radius $R$ with an angular acceleration $\alpha$. At the centre of the orbit is kept a conducting loop of radius $r$,$(r<<R)$. The emf induced in the smaller loop due to the motion of the electron is
column11:
$B=\frac{\mu_{0} e v R}{4 \pi R^{3}}$
$B=\frac{\mu_{0} e \omega R^{2}}{4 \pi R^{3}}$
$\phi=\frac{\mu_{0} e \omega}{4 \pi R} \times \pi r^{2}$
$\varepsilon=\frac{-d \phi}{d t}=\frac{\mu_{0} e \alpha r^{2}}{4 R}$

The percentage of intensity of incident unpolarized light that emerges from $B$

A radioactive material decays by two processes
$A$ and $B$ with half lives $\frac{1}{2}$ hour and $\frac{1}{4}$ hour respectively. Assume for the first half hour, it decays only with process $A$ and the next one hour with $B$. The next half hour, it decays both with $A$ and $B$. The original number of atoms in the material is $N_{0}$, then after two hours, the number of active atoms in the material is equal to $\mathrm{N}_{0} / 2^{x} .$ The value of $x$ is?
column11:
Initial $\frac{1}{2}$ hour $: T_{\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{~h}$, After $\frac{1}{2}$ hour $\rightarrow \frac{N_{0}}{2}$
Next $1$ hour: $T_{\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{1}{4} \mathrm{~h}$, After $1$ more hour
$\rightarrow \frac{N_{0}}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2^{4}}=\frac{N_{0}}{2^{5}}$
Further $\frac{1}{2}$ hour : $T_{\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{1}{6} h$,
After $\frac{1}{2}$ more hour $\frac{N_{0}}{2^{5}} \cdot \frac{1}{2^{3}}=\frac{N_{0}}{2^{8}}$

column3: Refer to the arrangement of logic gates. For $A=0$, $B=0$ and $A=1, B=0$, the values of output $Y$ are, respectively $P$ and $Q$, The sum of $P$ and $Q$ is
The voltage drop across a forward biased diode is $0.7 \mathrm{~V}$. In the following circuit, the voltage across the $10 \mathrm{~ohm}$ resistance in series with the diode will be
column11:
The Potential is calculated using the KVL rule.
$V_{10 ~\Omega}=\frac{(10-0.7)}{2}=4.65$

column3: In the circuit shown in figure ammeter and voltmeter are ideal if $E=6 \mathrm{~V}, R=15 ~\Omega$ and $r=1 ~\Omega$, then the reading of the voltmeter is (round off upto three significant figures)

column11:
$I_{d}=\varepsilon_{0} \frac{d \phi}{d t}$
hence dimension $[A]$
The dimension of Ampere is $1$.
